Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA top chef has shared his five secrets to making perfect roast potatoes - and revealed the common cooking mistakes we all make. Award-winning Michelin-starred cook Jeff Baker, who has fed the likes of the Queen, previously told us how we were cooking sausages and bacon wrong. And now the Executive Development Chef, who works at  Farmison  Co , has lted the lid on how to rustle up delicious tasting roasties every time. The roast potato is a staple addition to our Christmas dinner and arguably the best part, but they can be one of the most dficult components to perfect. Jeff has more than three decades experience in a professional kitchen, and has worked with some of the best in the business - so he knows his stuff. Here he shares his tips with .... You must buy fresh potatoes It may sound obvious, but having fresh potatoes to make roasties is the first step to perfection. You should never try to use old potatoes when cooking as they could be rotten which is sure to make you very, very ill. When you buy your potatoes, you should inspect them for any signs of mould or damage and then place the perfect potatoes in a cardboard box or paper bag - this ensures the best ventilation. To store, put your potatoes in a cool and dark place that is approximately  to  degrees Fahrenheit. Make sure to check your potatoes whilst they are being stored, as they may become soft and shrivelled and will, therefore, need to be thrown away.. Know your King Edward from your Maris Piper  Yes, there are perfect potatoes for roasting! By choosing the best potato for the job you can ensure that you will get the gorgeous crispy edges and fluffy centres that we all dream of. I would recommend King Edwards or Maris Pipers, which are readily available this time of the year. However, your standard white potatoes will also work, you just may need to give them a good shake in a sieve after par-boiling to fluff them up.. Stay away from soggy roasties  A mistake can be made in trying to crisp up your potatoes by almost drowning them in oil, leaving them burnt on the outside and undercooked on the inside. This is why it is important to fluff up your potatoes before roasting by partially boiling or using my preferred method of steaming. You can parboil your spuds for ten minutes in salted water or steam for  minutes . Be sure to allow your potatoes to dry and cool slightly before roasting.  . Feeding the   Your roasties will need some room…  As most of us are cooking for our whole family at Christmas time, we will be making a lot of food and lots of roast potatoes. If you’re making more than usual, several trays are recommended instead of forcing them all on one tray. This is because the potatoes need the space to crisp up in the oil or you run the risk of them becoming soggy as they sit in the oil. So make sure that you grab an extra roasting tray or two so that all your hard work does not go to waste!. Yes, it all comes down to the perfect timing The debate of how long you should cook your spuds is definitely up for contesting around Christmas time. However, it is down to several factors that many aren’t aware of, such as how big the potatoes are. I would recommend at least  minutes at °C  °C fan assistedwhilst checking every - minutes and giving them a shake to increase the crispiness.

title: tesco aldi sainsburys customers slam
story: NewsTesco, Aldi and Sainsburys customers slam slimy and rotten Christmas turkeysTesco, Sainsburys, Aldi and Morrisons customers have reported unwrapping their turkeys ahead of Christmas to discover their festive birds were rotten and smellyShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsRicky Yates was one of the people forced to bin their rotten turkey " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChristmas Day has got off to a stinking and miserable start for merry makers who claim they unwrapped their turkeys to discover them rotten and fetid. Some people who purchased festive poultry from Tesco, Sainsburyaposs, Aldi and Morrisons had to make last minute changes to their dinner plans when they say they discovered the meat was rotten. Divya Gill bought her turkey on December and came to prep it for the big day on Christmas Eve. When she did she says she discovered it was stinking and out of date. Absolutely appalled at Morrisons to buy a turkey two days ago and to open it to prep today for it to be completely out of date - as in my dog started gagging - when the sell by date is the th, Divya said. Lucky that we opened it today and MS had plenty of not rotten food left. Vicky Broomhead also had issues with the turkey she bought from Morrisons. Have you had a Christmas dinner disaster  Email webnews@mirror She said: I have just come to prep my turkey to go in the oven and it stinks. It has gone off so now thereaposs no turkey for family on Xmas day.Morrisons was not the only supermarket chain to come under fire from disgruntled Christmas dinner enthusiast.James Davies claims he picked up his bird from an Aldi on December  and placed it in the fridge as soon as he got home. He said: When we came to cook it this afternoon, Christmas Eve, we were concerned by the nasty smell coming from it. Nevertheless, we still cooked it in the oven, but the smell still remained, and clearly the meat was rotten. Our Christmas dinner is completely ruined for tomorrow. We have no replacement. Ricky Yates has similarly been left one turkey short of a full dinner after claiming to discover his Aldi purchase was off.  We opened the turkey after all supermarkets were closed, and are now left with trimmings and a cheese board to fill Christmas lunch, he said. According to industry website britishturkey a turkey will smell very gamey, acrid or of ammoniait has gone off. The flesh could also have a greenish tinge and feel quite slimy. If in any doubt - donapost risk it - bin it, advice on its website reads. The flesh should be in good colour and look moist in appearance with no dry flaky patches. Beth noticed some of these tell-tale signs despite buying a turkey from Tesco on the evening of December  and quickly refrigerating it. I went to put prepare it onand it stinks to high heaven, she said.  It is slimy and stinks rotten. Not great on Christmas Eve night. Says the best before date is the th but clearly not. Ann Doggett had similar issues with her Sainsburyaposs bird. She said: Turkey consigned to the bin as the smell and grey slimy look of it was disgusting. Will be going to Sainsburyaposs boxing day for a refund. An Aldi spokesperson said: aposWe are sorry that, in a small number of instances, we did not meet our usual high-quality standards.

title: top chefs secret perfect gravy
story: NewsTop chefs secret to perfect gravy - and  other amazing Christmas cooking tipsMichelin starred chef Jeff Baker has shared his  tips for cooking up a delicious festive feast - and hopefully it will make the big day as stress-free as possibleShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  DEC NewsJeff Baker has shared his top Christmas cooking tips " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email We all know how stressful Christmas can be: finding the perfect gts, wrapping them, travelling far and wide to see family and then, to top it off, making the notoriously time-consuming Christmas Day dinner . But fear not! Jeff Baker, Executive Development Chef at Farmison  Co , has shared withhis  top tips for a stress-free festive feast. The award-winning Michelin-starred cook, who has fed the likes of the Queen, previously told us how we were cooking  sausages , bacon  and roast potatoes wrong.And now he has lted the lid on making the perfect gravy, turkey, cheese board and more. Here Jeff shares his tips and tricks... . Get the drinks in the fridge...now! Amongst the carnage of cooking times and counting plates, we usually forget about the drinks. To avoid any upset once your guests have arrived - pop your fizz, white wine or beer in the fridge as soon as you can. Not your tipple  If you’re partial to a bottle of red, ensure that it’s been opened a few hours before dinner to let it breathe and intensy the flavour. . Pre-feast nibbles to satisfy all the guests Don’t faff around with fancy canapes and waste valuable cooking time! Whipping up super speedy nibbles couldn’t be any easier.  Smoked meats and fish make for a tasty and simple selection whilst you prepare for the main event. Simply serve with sourdough and condiments of your choice. This tip means that you can get back to perfecting your feast without worrying about entertaining your guests. . A scrumptious starter fit for a feast If you are looking to impress with an indulgent intro to your dinner, baked figs with fresh goats curd and truffle honey will go down a treat. Bake the figsin a cool oven at about °c with the truffle honeyuntil tender . Next, mix together with walnut oiland sherry vinegar , toss in with some rocket leaves and distribute the contents into  bowls. Add the figs and curdinto each bowl and scatter over some broken walnuts. . The perfect gravy  Easy peasy  There’s no need to cut corners and reach for the instant gravy this Christmas. After roasting your Christmas bird, simply tip the excess fat from your roasting tray and add stock of your choice . With the stock in the tray, scrape any leftover meat sediment into the stock and boil to reduce the volume. Add herbs of your choice and pass the liquid through a fine sieve into a clean pan. Want a real rich treat  Reduce the gravy to a syrup texture and whisk in a large knob of cold unsalted butter and enjoy! . Roasties from the freezer  I don’t think so…  Arguably the most dficult element of the Christmas spread are the roast potatoes. My top tip is to peel, wash, and steam your potatoes until they are just cooked. This will usually take around  minutes. Once cooked, melt duck fat and toss through the potatoes and season with sea salt. Place on a non-stick tray in a preheated oven set at c, and roast until golden - it’s best to turn them every  mins to ensure this . . How to get the most out of your meat: Turkey  To get the best flavour as well as use up as much of the meat as you can I would suggest to remove the giblets after roasting and keep them for the gravy later. On the day of roasting, sit the turkey in your kitchen and slowly bring it up to room temperature, this ensures an even roast - and don’t forget to weigh your turkey! Soften g of butter with the zest of a lemon, some sea salt, thyme leaves, and a splash of olive oil . Gently lt the skin away from the breast meat, starting at the cavity, and carefully push the softened butter between the skin and flesh. To stuff, cut an onion in two and place it into the cavity with the rindless lemon and a carrot with some fresh sage. Now put the turkey on a wire trivet and place in a preheated oven at °c for  minutes. Then pour ml of water onto the base of the tray and cover the turkey with tin foil. Reduce the heat to °c and roast  minutes per kilo, removing the tin foil for the last  minutes or so to colour the skin. To check the turkey is cooked, pierce the skin between thigh and breast and push the skewer into the flesh, close to the bone. If all has gone to plan, the juices should run clear. Ta da! . Struggle to get the kids to eat vegetables  They’ll ask for seconds with this tip To add extra flavour to carrots, turnips, parsnips and shallots, I simply place them together in a tin foil bag with a sprig of thyme or rosemary, a whole garlic clove, sea salt, and a teaspoon of duck fat. I then bake in the oven for a minimum of  hour until the vegetables are sweet and lightly caramelized. For green vegetables and brassica, I boil them in salted water until just cooked, then I refresh in ice-cold water and drain. To finish, I gently toss in a little butter and cracked pepper, sometimes with toasted almonds, caraway seeds or crispy smoked bacon and a few diced shallots. . An alternative to roast potatoes Yes, there are some people who don’t like the classic roastie. Luckily, parsnip and potato gratin is simple to make and acts as a scrumptious substitute to the royal roast potato. Mix warm equal amounts of whole milk and creamwith a couple of crushed garlic cloves, salt and ground white pepper. Once the mixture is nicely infused, pour it over g of thinly sliced potatoes mixed with g of thinly sliced parsnips. Layer in a gratin dish and bake at °c for  minutes, then continue to lower the heat to °c and cook for a further  minutes until the potatoes are tender. To ensure a cake like texture, press the gratin down now and again. . Mix up your pigs in blankets  Pigs in blankets are a staple at the Christmas table - but there’s no harm in mixing it up a little this year. Try wrapping a pitted prune in some Lancashire pancetta, insert a little sage leaf between the two items, and simply grill. These ‘devils on horseback’ go particularly well with goose and duck as well as all your other roasting birds. . Rich, buttery bread sauce, look no further Take  slices of brioche without crust and turn them into crumbs, then heat ml of whole milk with   diced onion and bouquet garni - then season with salt, pepper, and a little nutmeg. Pour the infused milk onto the breadcrumbs and cook on a gentle heat until slightly thickened. Then whisk in g of cold diced butter and keep at a warm temperature. This recipe can of course be made with simple white breadcrumbs for those guests who prefer a more traditional sauce. . Master your cheese board Serve cheeses made with dferent types of milk- ewe’s, cow’s, goat’s, even buffalo milk, or those made from a blend of milks. Each type of milk has a dferent flavour profile and this will make your selection more ied. Also think about ying textures, smooth, crumbly or sticky, they all make for a great cheese board. I would serve alongside semi dried fruits, some quality butter, and a biscuit or two. If you really want to push the boat out, you could opt for some fruit cheese or truffle honey. Before serving, remove cheeses from their packaging and leave uncovered at room temperature for at least an hour, or even longer. This way, the cheese can breathe and you’ll be able to taste the full spectrum of flavours in each. Be careful not to let the cheese touch each other too much as this can alter the flavour! . Never know what to do with the leftovers  Create another quick and delicious Boxing Day meal as a way to use up any leftover turkey! Dice  onions and soften with a crushed clove of garlic, then add a glass of dry white wine and boil into a syrup. Move on to add ml of poultry stock and ml of cream, bring to the boil and season with salt and pepper. Roughly slice a selection of mixed mushroomsand add to the sauce, then add your shredded turkey and a dozen or so chestnuts, walnuts or almonds to the mix. Simmer for  minutes on a low heat.

Perhaps the most ominous prediction of the clairvoyant was that the European continent could reach the end of its existence at the hands of Muslim extremists The Bulgarian suggested that extremists would use an arsenal of chemical weapons against Europeans”. Supporters of Baba are keen to emphasise how spot on she has been, with % accurate a phrase that regularly crops up in fan forums. According to baba-vanga, the figure is drawn from research conducted by Professor Georgi Lozanov - a former director of the Bulgarian Institute of Suggestology. Others point to her past successes as proof that she had foresight beyond that of a typical human.  In  she guessed that America would be hit by two apossteel birdsapos in a terror attack, in what was later interpreted as a reference to  . She said: Horror, horror! The American brothers will fall after being attacked by the steel birds. The wolves will be howling in a bush, and innocent blood will be gushing. Babaaposs big breakthrough had come a year earlier however, when she accurately predicted the sinking of Russian submarine the Kursk. Before cancelling Christmas and ordering a nuclear bunker however, readers should know that some questions remain around Baba and her predictions - some of which have been proved to be way off the mark.  Her prophecy that Europe would cease to exist by  was clearly wrong, unless seen through an incredibly generous Brexiteer lense. Babaaposs suggestion that the  FIFA World Cup final would be played between two teams beginning with the letter aposbapos was equally wrong. The nuclear war pencilled in for the years  to  also failed to materialise. Perhaps more damning is the seemingly non-existent nature of her prophecies. While Baba may have spoken or written down her predictions in Bulgarian, no credible version is available to view. According to a  Washington Post investigation, the few prophecies that can be traced back to their origins appear to come from Russian social media. When Bulgarian newspaper  Chasa interviewed Babaaposs neighbours, they said she had never predicted  , the sinking of the Kursk or the big war.

title: alex presents a compelling case to back up his nicklaus dates
story: Monieth reader Alex Kelly previously expressed doubt regarding dates given in this column for the visit of a sports superstar to the city.As far back as May this year, Andy Walker relayed his version of events when star golfer Jack Nicklaus visited the NCR factory in Dundee to give workers an exhibition of his skills.Andy reckoned the event took place in  but Alex begged to dfer.He said: “Following an investigation of the DC Thomson archives, courtesy of the Wellgate’s excellent local history resources, I found confirmation that Jack Nicklaus attended NCR on July , , to give a golf clinic to all NCR staff.“Furthermore, Jack Nicklaus was staying at the NCR guest house on the Perth Road with his mother and father.“As per my original email, Mr Nicklaus was driven to and from the event at NCR in a chauffeur-driven car.“Consequently, Mr Walker’s anecdote about him getting lost in Lochee does seem unlikely.“The chauffeur was a local person and would frequently drive visitors to and from the Perth Road house to the NCR factory.“I was present at Mr Nicklaus’ clinic along with several of my friends and fellow co-workers.“Indeed, I recall the excitement in the NCR when it was advertised to all staff that he was going to be there on that day.“And it was a pre-advertised event for all staff – it was not just for management.“Proof of that is that some workers arranged for their children to attend as well.”Alex worked with the NCR company between  and , and he continued: “That was the only time I can ever recall Mr Nicklaus, or any other famous golfer for that matter, giving a golf clinic at the NCR grounds.“This is backed up by the fact that there is no evidence in the archives that Mr Nicklaus attended NCR at the time of the  Open Championship, as per Mr Walker’s claim.”Alex supplied photos of the Eveningreport the following day. vw, px"

title: cctv images show the moment customer tackled crook in dundee newsagents
story: Shocking CCTV images show the moment a crook robbed a city newsagents – and police have revealed they are following a positive line of inquiry into the attempted heist.A Dundee shopkeeper has praised a have-a-go-hero customer who tackled a man brandishing a weapon inside the store.Arsalan Haider, Court Street News manager, released images this week of the incident which police are still investigating.Pictures show the customer #hugging# the man after he had reportedly swung wildly at the -year-old shopkeeper in a fit of rage after demanding cash.Police confirmed they are following a #positive line of inquiry# into the incident which took place on Wednesday December .Arsalan said the woman was a regular customer before thanking her today for her actions during the disturbance which took place shortly after pm that day.Describing the incident he said the man had used a metal frame from a chewing gum stand at the front counter before the customer intervened.He added: #If that customer hadn#t have been here it could have got worse # she massively defused the situation by taking the man outside.#I#d pushed the panic alarm during the incident before he fled the scene. It has all been caught on CCTV but the guy was swinging the bulky metal frame at me as he was demanding cash.#The ordeal within the store had gone on for around  minutes before the situation escalated.He added: #I was surprised and thankful that a customer had chosen to intervene in the matter.#The police came and took the CCTV footage from the incident and they knew of the man involved.#Court Street News has been targeted in a spate of incidents in recent years with Arsalan being assaulted during a disturbance in August .He added: #We have taken every measure to try and deter these incidents from happening, with CCTV and panic alarms, but these things continue to happen.#Given the troubles in the past the customers weren#t surprised to hear what has happened here last week.#Thankfully no one was injured but theyare worried because of everything that#s happened in the past that we might close the shop.#A spokesman for the force added: #We are following positive lines of inquiry.#

title: mcghee about time dee laid a glove on united
story: Dundee defender Jordan McGhee says it’s about time the Dark Blues laid a glove on Dundee United this season.McGhee and his team-mates have suffered twice at the hands of their local rivals, - at Tannadice and then a poor - defeat on home turf the last time they met.And the former Hearts and Falkirk man is keen to put that right on Friday night as the two go head to head once more at the home of league leaders United.McGhee told the Tele: “We want to do ourselves justice this time.“We have to lay a glove on United – the last two times we didn’t.“In derbies you have to earn the right to play first of all and we’ve fallen short.“We need to put our own stamp on the game and then relax and play our normal game.“Derbies are always dferent.“It doesn’t matter how well you are playing or how well the opposition are playing, it’s just about who wants it most on the day.“Whoever executes the gameplan best and keeps the head normally wins the game.“Regardless of how many they’ve won in a row, it would be nice to win a derby, not only for ourselves as players, but also for the fans and the club. vw, px"  “Eventhey had lost their last nine games, there would be massive pressure on us to win anyway.”McGhee admits that pressure has been on all season at Dens Park during some dficult spells.However, he expected nothing  after signing for the club in the summer.The -year-old is the club’s only ever-present in the league this season and is keen to maintain his consistent start to le at Dens Park.He added: “I’ve played every game which I’m quite proud of coming into a new club.“I’m delighted the gaffer has shown the faith in me to do that and I can’t thank him or the club enough for giving me the chance.“I knew coming to Dundee I had to up my game with the size of the club and the players I would be playing with.“I am used to that after playing at Hearts with the pressure there is at a club like that.“My aim was to take myself back to that level and I feel I’ve done that this season.“I need to keep moving forward, work hard and see where it takes us.”Dundee head into Friday night with two welcome wins at their backs and McGhee was delighted to notch a clean sheet in a - win at Partick over the weekend.“It was a good win down at Partick,” he said.“I think we could have scored more goals but we did play really well.“We created chances and I can’t really remember them having many, apart from when Kenny Miller hit the bar on the break.“It was a good performance and set us up to look forward to Friday night’s game.“It was a comfortable end to the game for us.“The boys worked their socks off which makes things easier for us defenders.“I didn’t feel threatened at all during the entire game which is pleasing – that’s not happened every week this season for us.“To get a clean sheet, too, is great for the confidence at the back to take into Friday night.“I think the last two games were among our best ones of the season, apart from the last half-hour against Dunfermline obviously.“It feels like we are starting to click and can try to get some consistency going, get points on the board, keep churning away and see where it takes us.”

title: best wishes for xmas
story: Community and religious leaders along with some well-known faces pass on their festive wishes to the people of the north-east vw, px"  “I’m spending Christmas with my family in Peterhead this year, which always makes it extra special. I’m also really looking forward to watching the Dons on Boxing Day with all my old friends.“ was kind of bitter sweet for me personally. On the one hand it was great to have success with Stan  Ollie and all the positivity that came from that, but it was frustrating to see the country so ided due to the political situation. I’m therefore looking forward to a fresh start for people in Scotland going into the next decade.“I’d like to wish everyone in the north-east a very happy Christmas and a prosperous and peaceful New Year.” vw, px"  “Christmas is the season of good will to all, and I would like to take this opportunity to wish the people of Aberdeen ‘all the very best’ over the festive period and hope that everyone enjoys a healthy, happy and prosperous .“ has been a fantastic year in the le of Aberdeen. We have welcomed key milestones – the opening of PJ Live and the reopening of Aberdeen Art Gallery.“ is set to be another exciting year with the redevelopment of Provost Skene’s House, the expansion of Aberdeen Harbour and the reinvigoration of Union Terrace Gardens continuing at pace.“On a personal note, I’ve had the privilege of meeting more wonderful people during  in my roles of Lord Provost and Lord Lieutenant.“It’s been a busy year and I’m looking forward to spending time with my family at Christmas, but not everyone is so fortunate. It can be a stressful and lonely time for many, and we need to look out for each other, not just for Christmas but always.” vw, px"  “As we come to the end of , this time of year is always an opportunity for me to reflect on the past year and look ahead to what  may bring.“For the past  months I have been in the privileged position to witness the positive and tireless work being carried out by police officers, staff, special constables and youth volunteers within your communities. Signicant reductions in acquisitive and violent crimes have been recorded as well as increased detection rates, while our efforts have continued to tackle illegal drugs and support the most vulnerable people.“Given the nature of the work of emergency services, it will be business as usual for many police officers and police staff over the next couple of weeks. They don’t know what they will be called to or who they will need to help, but what I do know is that each call will be handled with the same professionalism and compassion that is experienced the rest of the year.“On behalf of everyone within North East Division, I wish you all a very happy and safe Christmas and a peaceful New Year.” vw, px"  “Blythe Yule in Aiberdeen vw, px"  “On behalf of Her Majesty The Queen and the Aberdeenshire Lieutenancy, I wish everybody a very Happy Christmas and good wishes for .“I have welcomed many new citizens to Aberdeenshire this year and, like me, I am sure they find this county to be an inspiring place to live, whether coming from the mountains or near the sea, and with a erse community who thrive, work and enjoy everything this wonderful area has to offer.” vw, px"  “This time of year provides us with a chance to reflect on the months gone by and to consider the year ahead.“However you plan to spend it, I wish all readers of the Evening Express a very happy Christmas and a wonderful New Year.” vw, px"  “As we have a game on Boxing Day, Christmas Day will be another normal working day for us, as it always is, but I’d like to wish Dons supporters everywhere, and their families, a very Merry Christmas and hopefully we can reward them with three points against Livingston.” vw, px"  “It’s been a year of change for AFC, with the opening of our amazing training facilities at Cormack Park, some new faces on the board and a partnership with Atlanta United.“We’re excited about the future for our club and look forward to a new year which will see us focus on delivering on and off the pitch, particularly in greater fan engagement and match-day experience. I’d like to thank everyone at or involved with the club for all their hard work and support in  and wish Dons’ fans, wherever they are in the world, a happy Christmas. Stand free!”“Christmas is a time to come together with friends and family to celebrate.“At this time of year, when many people are looking forward to the holiday season, it is particularly upsetting that many people in our own city are struggling to put food on the table.“Throughout the year, my office staff have been collecting for food banks across the city and have made a number of deliveries.“If you can spare a can or other non-perishable item this Christmas, it would be greatyou could deliver this to your local food bank to help those in need.“Wishing everyone in Aberdeen a very Merry Christmas and a wonderful New Year.” vw, px"  “This is an exciting and defining time for our region with the transformational opportunities afforded by energy transition alongside the ersication and innovation being driven by Opportunity North East in our wider economy. I look forward to that continuing to grow in . A very Merry Christmas to all of you and your families.” vw, px"  “May I wish everyone a joyful Christmas and all good things for ! We don’t know the future, but we do know that God is with us – always, everywhere.“And that changes everything.“However you may celebrate or spend Christmas, this time of year has the potential to change us and something can sht in us through celebrating it.“From the signicance of Christ dwelling amongst us portrayed in the scriptural story flows the modern day witnesses of ‘change’ illustratedin ious media, such as Scrooge in A Christmas Carol, to George Bailey in It’s a Wonderful Le, and there are of course many other examples.“Something new can enter and change our standard selves. A new meaning of le is experienced.“At Christmas, God changed. God became something he was not: a human being. Humanity became part of God, forever.“At Christmas, God changed. He changed, so as to change us.“He took on us so that we can take on him.“God lived a human le so we can – unbelievably – live a ine one. With the help of the Holy Spirit and in the limits of our humanity, we can reflect the goodness of God – freely, out of love.“To humble ourselves, like God. Trying to serve one another, as Jesus did.“And that changes us. Perhaps one simple le-changing gesture for Christmas is to remember – in prayer and contact – someone we might otherwise not.“Couldn’t the whole world then become changed by love ”

title: ex don tosh and club help families in need
story: Aberdeen’s Former Players’ Association have donated cash this Christmas to a local charity dedicated to helping the underprivileged.AberNecessities has been appointed the Former Players’ Association’s chosen charity for the upcoming year.The cash donation was also boosted with Aberdeen FC providing  season tickets through the club’s Aberdeen For All initiative.The award-winning Aberdeen FC Community Trust also purchased gts for the children.Former Aberdeen midfielder Steve Tosh, a committee member on the Former Players’ Association, insists it was important to send a message of support to those in need during the festive period.Tosh said: “We felt it was a timely and powerful message for former professional players and the local football club, with an award-winning football trust, to work together and send a real message of support to those in need at Christmas time.”The donations were presented to Danielle Flecher-Horn from AberNecessities at Pittodrie.AberNecessities’ aim is to support local, underprivileged families in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire with essential items they need to care for their babies and children.The charity accepts donations of nappies, wipes, children’s toiletries, nearly new clothes , toys and equipment.Tosh, who starred for Aberdeen from  to ’, said: “AberNecessities is an amazing local charity, making real dference to peoples lives, and we’re honoured to play a small part in that.’Abernecessities also received family tickets for the Paw Patrol shows next year as well as toys from Imajica and PJ Live.Steven Sweeney, chief operating officer at Aberdeen FC Community Trust, said: “Aberdeen is a club that cares passionately about people.“There is a genuine family feeling and that is why we are determined to take our responsibility to our communities seriously. title: negotiating the modern world
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsWhy is it so hard to negotiate the modern world That is the question asked by Dame Helen Mirren in the Radio Times. It is encouraging to know that beauty, fame and fortune do not insulate you from the insanities of everyday le.An infuriating attempt to find out the time of an audiology appointment at a national chain of chemist shops would provide material for a comedy show, as long as you were not the people concerned.A friend had arranged this appointment, but on the morning concerned had left behind her diary. Knowing the patient#s name, date of birth, address and audiologist#s name were not enough # post code was the key.  Her home post code did not work, the current one and a friend#s were rejected but inspiration struck and the previous hospital proved acceptable.Without best friend Google and someone to search for information, the day would have been ruined by the interpretation of data protection laws. The anomaly which made this ludicrous was that they were quite willing to cancel the appointment on the say so of the person they did not trust with the time.Have you had the frustration of doing a large supermarket shop early enough to beat the crowd, only to find you can#t add beer, evenit is labelled zero per cent alcohol  I fantasised about a situation where all the alcohol free wine, lager and even gin was made available, tempted people to sample, find jolly good and demand that the ied brands be available in pubs and eating places, instead of the ubiquitous coke.Alas, the alcohol trace in some of  these products mean that all fall foul of government policy. An excellent intention and the law of unintended consequences.

title: letters to the editor november 8 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In last week#s letters page you ran a version of the very long open letter addressed to me from the local SNP MP and MSP, a letter that they found the time to send to the press, but didn’t have the courtesy to send to me directly.On the council, all councillors work well together – particularly when addressing the major challenges the council faces. Last year the SNP councillors supported the administration’s budget, this year there were only slight dferences between the administration’s budget and the SNP’s one.It would be great to see our MP and MSP work with the council to make the case to the Scottish Government for more money for Argyll and Bute. COSLA has made a very clear request of the Scottish Government in terms of funding for local councils next year – three per cent plus inflation. The choices facing the council would be substantially dferentthis was delivered and of course it’s the Scottish Cabinet, including our MSP, who actually make the decisions.The fact is that over the past  years, the council has had to make savings of over £million. That means real hardship for many local people – many jobs lost, many services withdrawn. That is the sad reality.Like all councillors I#m sure, I would be happy to work with the local MP and MSP to make the case for more funding for Argyll and Bute.Councillor Aileen Morton, Argyll and Bute Council leaderSir,Regarding council leader Aileen Morton’s comments in the edition of the Advertiser dated October  # why should the public tolerate more cuts to their services year on yearthey are consistently paying their council tax and other taxes This seems unfair and should be challenged. Surely council leader Morton should be saying to the Scottish Government that the funding provided is not enough and we can’t make any more cuts.Instead of a reduced budget, the council should be asking for an increased budget to operate services when you consider all the cutbacks to their budget over the past few years.Perhapsthe situation was made clear to the Scottish Government by local councils that annual cuts to local authority services cannot be sustained, this situation will stop.It is unfair on council staff too, with threats of cutbacks having a negative effect on their own jobs through no fault of their own. Adding more work to an employee already struggling with their workload causes more stress which is not good for staff or their employer.Instead of accepting a reduced budget, please therefore can the budget be challenged and not accepted Peter Laing, LochgilpheadSir,Being non-funded, Mojo Festival of Original Music relies on my own initial outlay and the kindly volunteering of the team to help achieve at least a small bonus for all the hard working and talented acts who put on a really good night at the event.This year, even though we had more expenses, we had an even bigger attendance which meant we made roughly the same profit as last yearto share out, giving the bands £ each. Also the bands sold tickets along with their merchandise to give an extra £ approx to the cause. We had a total of  people in attendancewhich is our best ever turnout.The best part though was how much everyone enjoyed what was a night of some of the best original music Argyll has to offer # and you can#t put a price on that. Well done to all who were there and supported the whole event.Dan and crew, Mojo organisersSir,Among the many concerns caused by you-know-what is the very real fear that hospitals and high street pharmacies will run out of vital medical supplies which would normally arrive from factories in Malta, Hungary and Poland.So why are generic medicines not made in Lochgilphead, in Campbeltown and in Rothesay  After all, calcium supplement tablets are made in Galashiels by a Japanese brewery company.Glasgow Health Board built a brand new wee factory on the Western Infirmary Glasgow University campus  years to manufacture some but not all of their requirements. Not only did this save a great deal of money but the board  also earned considerable extra income by selling their products to other health boards, including Dumbarton and Argyll.All in all, the costs of building and equipping the Hillhead factory proved to be a very sound investment indeed.Duncan I Macdougall, TarbertSir,I write following last week#s open letter by SNP politicians Mike Russell and Brendan O#Hara in which they attempted to evade responsibility for the budget problems facing Argyll and Bute Council.These comments display extraordinary hypocrisy, revealing how out-of-touch these SNP politicians are with the realities of the challenges facing Argyll and Bute Council.The financial pressures on this council are a direct consequence of the repeated unfair financial settlements imposed on the council by the SNP government over the last  years.Brendan O#Hara should get on the phone to Nicola Sturgeon and demand a fair deal for Argyll and Bute instead of blaming everyone .Donald Cameron MSP, Highlands and Islands

title: science matters human impact on climate change then and now
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowHuman activity from the industrial revolution onwards is causing global warming which,not halted, will have catastrophic consequences.Now scientists suggest that human activity several centuries earlier also caused climate change*. But this had the opposite effect # cooling # resulting in the #Little Ice Age# between the th to th centuries.#In  Columbus sailed the ocean blue#, #discovering# the Americas and heralding unprecedented prosperity for Europeans. But for indigenous Americans it caused rapid, massive loss of le. This was mainly caused by the spread of lethal, Eurasian microbes carried by the Conquistadors. Literally thousands of infectious diseases, including smallpox, measles, scarlet fever, diphtheria and scarlet fever, killed millions of Americans who had no immunity or genetic resistance against them.#The Great Dying# saw the population plummet by  per cent, the final death toll being around  million. So began a chain of events which, scientists say, cooled the whole hemisphere.The Great Dying caused abandonment of approximately  million hectares of cultivated land – an area over twice size of UK. Natural reforestation of this land increased carbon uptake by plants, leading to a  consequent decline in atmospheric CO and finally a decrease in temperature – the Little Ice Age.  This theory is supported by coincident changes in local pollen deposits and by Antarctic ice-core records revealing trapped air bubbles from this time period with low CO levels.Any lessons for today Unfortunately, today#s problems are on a completely dferent scale. Reduction in CO by reforestation in the th century was comparable to just two years worth of fossil fuel emissions today.*A Koch et al. Quaternary Science Reviews -.

title: letters to the editor november 15 2019
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I concur wholeheartedly with Rev Mackenzie’s concerns, the Argyllshire Advertiser, November , about the dangers surrounding the Cairnbaan road junction with the A.I had to make representations to the council about road signs being covered by vegetation last year.I travel through this junction most days of the week, often several times per day. Those of us familiar with it know full well to treat it with respect and to be particularly careful when coming away from Cairnbaan towards Lochgilphead.Like Rev Mackenzie, I am aware of a number of accidents there over the last  months. I would estimate at least five,not more. This is a hugely disproportionate amount compared with other junctions on this road. That fact alone should ring alarm bells with the roads authority.This, however, is not the be-all-and-end-all. I have personally witnessed more near misses at the junction than I would care to mention. The problem comes particularly, but not exclusively, during the height of the tourist season with drivers who are not familiar with the area.Rev Mackenzie quite rightly points out there is a deceptive vista that appears to make the road look like a long straight one and despite the presence of warning signs, for some reason, these are ignored.I thought it rather a trite response from Argyll and Bute Council, which is effectively saying the junction meets all legal requirements sign wise and motorists need to be more aware. It is effectively shrugging its shoulders about the reality of the situation and refusing to take the constant presence of risk seriously.It really does need someone to come up with a genuine solution that will eliminate these risks as far as humanly possible and hopefully curtail the number of incidents that will inevitably occur in futurenothing positive is done.Peter J Garrett, Ardrishaig.Sir,We are now into gloomier weather conditions and on occasions a low sun casts long shadows on our roads.I have advice for cyclists who venture on to the highways wearing black hats, black jackets, black trousers, black shoes, carrying black bags and riding their black bikes.Wear clothes that enhance your visibility, please.Earlier this year, in such conditions, I passed such a cyclist on my way into Oban. He was just starting on the incline out of Kilmore so the black tarmac was his background.It was his moving right foot on the pedal I noticed. At first I thought it was a dog on the road until my headlights picked him up.Tom Cullen, Dunskeig, Ardfern.We would like to invite readers to nominate a deserving carer for a chance of going on a free holiday, while the person they care for comes on a free break with us, Revitalise, through our new Grace Award for Caring.Carers save the economy £ billion per year, which is more than the NHS budget. The Grace Award for Caring was named not only because it takes grace to care for someone, but because it takes grace to accept care from someone.To nominate a carer visit www.revitalise.org.uk graceawards or call  .Abby Kessock-Philip, Revitalise.Sir,From October to December, deer are more likely to be on the road as they move down to lower ground to find food and shelter.The majority of collisions take place in early evening through to midnight, with another peak from am to am.Particularly in these peak times, we advise motorists to slow down and watch for deer crossing roads.Deer can suddenly appear before you have time to brake. If you do hit a deer, report it to the police, evenyou are uninjured and your car is not damaged, as the deer may be fatally injured and suffering.Jamie Hammond, SNH management officer.

title: south argyll schools dig out hard fought win
story: Words by Lee BuckleyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsAn Argyll schools rugby team produced an impressive performance to grind out a hard-fought victory against East Dunbartonshire opposition.South Argyll Schoolsunder- boys team, made up of players from Lochgilphead, Tarbert and Campbeltown high school pupils competed in their final regional schools quaich group game of the season against Boclair Bearsden on Thursday November .After St Thomas Aquinas failed to raise a team for the first game of the group, SAS were then narrowly beaten away to Lomond School and at home to Shawlands Academy. The games were well contested, and the Argyll boys could have won both games. Two lapses of concentration against Lomond let them in for easy tries and only two points separated the teams in the Shawlands game at the end, when SAS had been in the lead for large parts of the match.The whole team thought it was important to finish the group with a good home win.The boys set out their stall early at MacRae Park when a contested ruck ended with a good turnover from SAS number seven McLean and a great pass out to winger Gritten from number eight McColl-Smith, who then released MacKay. The full back ran  yards to score under the posts and then convert his own try.SAS were next on the score sheet when Captain Donald Self went over the whitewash. MacKay converted and SAS were  –  up.Some good play from both teams was making for a great game, enjoyed by a large home crowd. Pupils were given the chance to watch the game and they made their voices heard and, spurred on by the crowd, Euan MacArthur was next on the score sheet and once again MacKay converted the try.The first half finished - to the home team.The second half started with Boclair coming back at SAS and, after some good running, they pulled a try back.SAS found themselves under sustained pressure and soon Boclair had a second try. Only one try was converted, and the score was -. Another try, this one converted, for Boclair and the pressure was really on.South Argyll thought they had secured the game when Ellis went over and grounded the ball only to realise he had gone over the dead ball line. No try and the pressure was on again. Minutes later, after some great forward work to turn the ball over, McArthur again went over for South Argyll#s fourth try. Another two points from MacKay made the score -.After the restart Boclair went all out to get another score. Great defensive work from the SA backs kept Boclair out for a sustained period of attack until, with only seconds to go, the scored their fourth try.As the conversion attempt fell short the final whistle blew and South Argyll celebrated a hard-fought win.While South Argyll didn not get out of the group stages they can be very pleased with third place,only one point behind second spot.

title: meet the 2019 mojo lineup the blue moon travellers
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSheila McWhirter from The Blue Moon Travellers was tasked with answering on behalf of the duo.. Describe your music in three words.Quality. Acoustic. Mellow.. What is it that drives you to keep making your own music Jim and I agree that it is simply a lovely gt to have the opportunity to make original music. I guess the desire to say or make something original and to be creative drives us as well.. If you could put one of your tracks in a time capsule for future generations to remember your music by what would the killer tune be The title track from album, Into the Blue.. Where and when was your last gig and how did it go Our last gig was a Clachan homesong concert. It was fab! Small scale but a quality audience in a unique setting.. How do you best wind down after a gig We used to party all night but we are flagging# A wee chat and a wee glass or two of something strong mair like it noo # we#re no deid yet!. If you could choose one person from music history, alive or dead, to have a drink with who would it be and why Gosh sooo many but I think I would mostly want to relate to them through their music. Dead # Gram Parsons. Alive # Joni Mitchell# maybe . What has been the best moment of your music venture so far Surviving some major challenges and having a finished product which people seem to like.. What advice would you give to musicians trying to play their own music here in Argyll.Take every opportunity to get out playing live #the gigs don#t exist make them happen. Be grateful for every moment # it goes by too fast. Work with your ego # don#t be an asshole to folk, especially not sound engineers! Don#t believe the hype but be confident in your abilities.. What#s next So much to come, very exciting. Some great gigs coming and some new songs to shape up. Hoping to set up a Highlands and Islands tour post Easter and some more house concerts quality intimate gigs # we love them. Edinburgh Festival Fringe project in mind. Two new EPs in the making. This year’s winner, picked by the skipper, was Robert ‘Grinch’ MacBrayne.The day started off as expected, pretty cold with a few light showers. Fishing was slow at first with roughly an hour passing before the first catch came aboard, but after that it was non-stop until lunchtime.The quality of spurs and whiting was better than expected with very few undersized caught. Most made the measure and on average spurs hit the -cm mark with a couple of decent ones coming in at cm tipping the scales at lbs oz.As the day progressed the weather deteriorated with heavy showers, hail and really strong gusts spinning the boat leading to the inevitable Etive tangles.A decision was made to cut the day short and lines up was called at pm.Given the conditions everyone coped well and at the end of the day four species, spurs, whiting, lsd and pouting, added to the tally of  counting fish.Highlight of the day were the two sea eagles that flew in quite close on the hunt for food but they had their work cut out with so many greedy gulls around. title: v1p-treatment-borders-veterans-christmas
story: VETERANS from across the Borders got fired into some festive fare last week.The annual Veterans First Point Christmas dinner brings together former servicemen and women as well as representatives from many support agencies.This year a total of  veterans and their families enjoyed Christmas Dinner with staff from Veterans First Point acting as waiters.Haylis Smith, mental health strategy  commissioning manager at NHS Borders, told us: ldquoIt is a pleasure to be able to provide opportunities such as this throughout the year to enable veterans and their families to come together in a social setting and enjoy the company of others who have had similar experiences."The Christmas dinner has grown in popularity every year with the highest turnout yet this year - we may need a bigger venue next year.Veterans First Point provides a one-stop shop for ex service personnel who require support with employment, benefit and housing as well as access to psychological therapy when ing to civilian le.The VP Team comprises of both healthcare professionals and those with military experience.All the ingredients for this years Christmas dinner was donated by Bookers Cash  Carry.Aaron Biggs from Bookers said: ldquoThis year it is our upmost pleasure to supply everything for the Veterans First Point Christmas dinner, we owe our lives to these committed and brave men and women who fought on our behalf to allow us to have the lives we have today and for us as a team in Galashiels to provide this meal is a small token of our appreciation to each and every veteran that benefits from it.Bakery chain Greggs provide the food every week for the VP breakfast club.VP is open every Monday, Wednesday and Thursday from am until pm at the Hive in Galashiels, with the breakfast club open from am until pm on Thursdays.Health and social care officer Robert McCulloch-Graham added: ldquoVeterans First Point is an important and exciting service that continues to be well received and supported throughout the Borders."It is an especially important service at this time of year when spending time with family and support is especially signicant. If you are a veteran and are interested in finding out more or you just want to chat please come along.

title: peebles-high-school-lockers-emptied-belongings-collection
story: NEW arrangements have been made for Peebles High School students to collect their belongings from the school this week following the fire on November .SBC staff have now been able to retrieve belongings from more than  lockers from the two least affected areas of the school.Items found in the Millennium Wing, Science, Music, CDT areas and the John Muir House were available to collect from Tuesday, December from the schools assembly hall.After extensive safety checks, the assembly hall has been largely unaffected by the blaze so has been cordoned off from the rest of the school as a safe zone for collections.Yesterday, S-S students were accompanied by staff to the school and will again be chaperonedtodayto collect their belongings from the High School and to fill out a receipt form and make note of any missing items.Students from S-S will be able to visit the collection point from pm to pm tonight with a further chance to collect belongings made for tomorrow .Belongings have been organised into groups as: CDT - Music - Music - Music - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Lower Millennium - Upper Millennium - Science - CDT  and John Muir.Access to the school can be made through an entrace at the security fence on Bonnington Road.For items such as car keys, drivers licences etc which are missing, specic requests should be made to SchoolEstates@scotborders.gov.uk for their collection.For all updates on the Peebles High School Fire, visit www.scotborders.gov.uk phsfire

story: A LOCAL businessman has boosted this years Radio Borders Cash for Kids appeal with pound worth of gts.The charitys Mission Christmas volunteers are currently working tirelessly to fulfill this years , applications to provide gts for underprivileged children from around the Borders and North Northumberland.But this weeks bumper donation from Lauders Steven McIntosh will have helped.Steven, who is the managing director of Saltire Roofing and Building, told us: "Mission Christmas is very close to all our hearts at Saltire Roofing and Building and wersquore absolutely delighted to donate pound to the Radio Borders campaign this year."We hope these gts will bring happiness to lots of local children so that no child wakes up without a present on Christmas morning.Almost one in three children are reported to be living in poverty.And the Cash for Kids appeal makes sure all of them have a Christmas to remember for the right reasons.Emma Kemp, Cash for Kids regional charity manager, said: ldquoSaltire Roofing and Building do a lot to help Cash for Kids with our campaigns throughout the year, and Stevie is always incredibly generous in his donation to Mission Christmas."pound worth of gts is amazing and will help us to ensure that as many children as possible in the Scottish Borders receive presents this Christmas."Thank you so much to the team at Saltire Roofing and Building.

title: change-thomas-thea-drop-2019-borders-baby-names-chart
story: ITS all change in the Scottish Borders name game during  with last years top choices dropping completely out of the top ten.In  the most popular boys name in the Borders was Thomas, selected  times by new mums and dads, and Thea was the the top pick for girls.But neither name features in the  chart, which was published this week.For girls its a six-way tie for the most popular name in the Borders - Amelia, Ava, Ella, Lucy, Olivia and Willow - all being selected seven times during the year.And theres also a tie at the top of the boys chart.Finn, James, Lewis and Noah were all chosen eight times by parents.Making up the Borders boys top ten are Alfie, Jack, Oliver and William, who are tied for fth with seven selections each.And, being chosen six times, tied in ninth are Charlie, Hamish, Harris, Leo, Oscar, Rory and Theo.The girls chart for the Borders is completed by Ellie, Freya, Grace and Isla who are tied for seventh place with six selections each.Across Scotland Jack and Olivia remained the most popular first forenames for babies registered in .Jack has been the most popular boysrsquo name for  years running, while Olivia has been the top girlsrsquo name for a fourth consecutive year.Oliver remained the second most popular names for boys in Scotland.James stayed in third place, Charlie climbed seven places to fourth, Harris rose three places to fth, Noah was up three places at sixth, Lewis was down one place at seventh, Leo dropped three places to eighth, Rory rose one place to ninth and Alfie was up six places at tenth.Emily was again the second most popular name for girls. Isla and Sophie remained third and fourth, respectively, Ella rose one place to fth, Ameliaand Avawere joint sixth, Grace remained eighth, Freya climbed four places to ninth and Charlotte was up one place at tenth.National Records of Scotland registered the births of , boys and , girls.Parents chose , dferent first forenames for boys and , dferent first forenames for girls.Alan Ferrier, head of demographic statistics at National Records of Scotland said: "Once again Jack and Olivia are the most popular first names in Scotland, however, there have been some fascinating changes in the top names for .ldquoThe fastest climbers in the boysrsquo top  are Tommy and Arthur. Tommy is up  places to th and Arthur is up  places to th. For the girls, the big climbers are Gracie, Ayla and Hallie, who are now all in the top .ldquoJackson had the biggest fall in popularity for the boys names in the top , dropping  places to th, and for the girls it was Cara, down  places to joint th.

title: peebles-high-school-post-christmas-teaching-exams-revealed
story: PLANS for face-to-face teaching to continue for Peebles High School students after the Christmas break have been finalised.Arrangements for the upcoming prelim exams have also made.Since the fire which broke out in the school on Thursday, November , students from S-S have received face-to-face teaching from Peebles High staff in locations around Peebles, and S-S students have been taught by Peebles staff in Galashiels.Students willto their classes on Monday, January  with current teaching and transportation still in effect.S-S students will remain in Peebles and S-S students will stay in Galashiels until January  before their prelim exam leave begins on January .Scottish Borders Council has confirmed that all prelim exams for Peebles High students will be held in the High Schools new games hall complex, which wasnt damaged by the fire. These exams will run from Monday, January  until Friday, January .Prelim exams which had been postponed due to the fire will also be scheduled for this period.For the duration of the exam leave period curricular and pastoral drop-in support will be made available to students from the High School.Study spaces will be open at West Linton Primary School and St Ronans Primary School, Innerleithen, for any S-S students for the exam leave.Keen to have students back learning in Peebles High School as soon as possible, works in the school will continue over the Christmas break.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Chief Executive, Tracey Logan, said: ldquoAlthough work has started on the Peebles High School site, there remains a signicant amount of progress required before we can safely accommodate pupils back within the high school for full time education.ldquoThis includes repairing and reinstating essential services and putting in place temporary toilets and additional teaching space.ldquoAs a result, we have decided to keep the current temporary arrangements in place after the Christmas break as we work to finalise plans for getting all pupils back in to Peebles High School.ldquoThis an absolute priority for us and a signicant number of staff from right across the Council are working towards that aim. Teams will be working throughout the holidays and we will continue to keep pupils, parents and staff updated and confirm post-January arrangements as soon as possible.Contingency plans have been put in place for winter weather should this occur when the temporary arrangements are in place, and should these need to be activated the Council will communicate with parents through normal channels, including the Council website, social media channels, Radio Borders and Groupcall.Updates on Peebles High School can be found at www.scotborders.gov.uk phsfire

title: home-basics-bids-farewell-first-noel
story: A CHARITY in Walkerburn is todaywaving farewell to its first Noel.Over the past seven years former Harrods hospitality worker Noel Dashwood-Brady has been a key part of the success at Home Basics.With retail outlets in both Walkerburn and Hawick, the charity helps reduce waste, while ensuring affordable household items are available for customers on low incomes.But Noel, who has also ran his own hospitality recruitment agency in the past, is now calling it a day.And hes looking forward to a retirement on Innerleithen golf course.Home Basics chair Tracy Buchan told us: ldquoNoels unique contribution will be missed by all as during his time at Home Basics he has always been willing to get involved with every aspect of running the daily business."His hands-on approach has greatly assisted with everything from coffee mornings to helping in the warehouse and even driving the delivery van."Noel is a highly regarded member of the team and will be missed by colleagues and volunteers alike, as will his valuable contribution to the organisation. ldquoNoel started as a volunteer in the Walkerburn store in  before securing part time employment for the non-profit organisation in an administration role.Innerleithen Golf Club captain Roddy McClean added: "I look forward to seeing more of Noel at the course."He is an institution there. And what better way to spend your retirement than at the friendliest and most scenic course in the Borders."Home Basics is open to everyone and has stores in Walkerburn and Hawick.The charitys work supports people, the environment and the local community.

title: 39-year-old-knocked-partners-windows-three-hours
story: A -year-old man was thrown out of his partners home but repeatedly knocked on the door and windows for three hours before police were called.Blair Scott pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the domestic-related offence at a house in Kenilworth Avenue, Galashiels, on November .Kate Irwin, prosecuting, said: "The couple had been in a relationship for about a year. The complainer asked him to leave because she believed he had been involved in drugs."He went away but ed at .pm and was repeatedly striking the windows and doors wanting to get back in."This happened for the next three hours before the complainer eventually phoned the police."Sentence was deferred on Scott - now residing in Edinburgh - until January  to establishthere was any reason why a Non-Harassment Order should not be imposed in this case.

title: jeannie-jock-arrive-galashiels
story: THE final pieces of the Coulters Candy jigsaw were fitted last week.An eye-catching bronze statue of Robert Coltart - the sweetseller who composed the Ally Bally Bee song - was unveiled in September.Now two additional pieces, Little Jock and Wee Jeannie, have been added to complete the commemoration artwork in Galas Market Square.Both the boy and the girl were characters in verses of the world-famous lullaby.All three sculptures are the work of Innerleithen-based artist Angela Hunter.She said: "It is wonderful to see the figures of Wee Jeannie and Little Jock in place.ldquoThis completes the scenario honouring Robert Coltart which I hope will appeal to all ages and become an added attraction to Galashiels."I would also like to thank Powderhall Bronze for their hard work and support throughout this project."The story of sweetseller Coltart was championed by local historians Graeme McIver and Mary Craig.Mr McIver told us: ldquoThe song Coulterrsquos Candy is arguably Scotlandrsquos most loved childrenrsquos song so it is wonderful and appropriate to see Poor Wee Jeannie and Little Jock, names lted from verses, join the statue of Robert Coltart to complete Angela Hunterrsquos vision."Angela has managed to capture perfectly both the anticipation of the little boy rushing to purchase the sweets as well as the wee girl, sitting eating the famous candy. You can see the pleasure in the faces of what would have been poor, mill workersrsquo children.ldquoThe Coulterrsquos Candy statue has proved very popular since its unveiling back in September and Irsquom sure the addition of both children will make it an even more loved attraction that will delight young and old alike and visitors to the town as well as residents of Galashiels.The tribute is part of a town trail created by Scottish Borders Council, which includes a plaque at Coltartrsquos former home on Overhaugh Street.The project is supported by the Scottish Government who provided a pound.million grant last year to help fund a number of regeneration projects in the town, including new visitor signage and improvements to Channel Street and Douglas Bridge, as well as helping to fund the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor centre.Helen Calder, from the Energise Galashiels Trust, said: ldquoThe additions of the children Jock and Jeannie will help tell the story of the much loved candy man Robert Coltart.ldquoSince the Coulterrsquos Candy statue was installed in September, the Market Square is rarely without children and adults taking photos and reading the story all with smiling faces.ldquoI am very proud to have been involved in this wonderful project.

title: film-festival-launches-inaugural-photography-competition
story: THE forthcoming Peebles Outdoor Film Festival has launched its first-ever photography competition.And the winners wont just have the chance to win fabulous prizes but also have their work viewed by thousands of people over the festival weekend and beyond.Photographers of all ages are invited to submit images based on the theme of wildness.The deliberately-broad theme can cover a specic place, person, outdoor activity, wildle, landscape, or even just an expression, or feeling.Festival director Rich Rowe said: "It doesnrsquot matterthe images are taken on the fanciest of cameras, or a smartphone, what matters most is that the images tell a story and really stop us in our tracks.An independent  of judges will shortlist a dozen stand-out images that will then be mounted and displayed in the Eastgate Theatrersquos Anne Younger Studio for two weeks, including over the festival weekend.From the dozen images shortlisted, one photograph will be chosen as the winner of the grand prize.The winning photographer will receive a dayrsquos guided photo tour of the Tweed Valley in the expert company of Ian Linton ndash an outstanding local photographer who knows all the best shooting spots ndash plus one nightrsquos bed and breakfast stay at the award-winning Glede Knowe Guest House, Innerleithen.The grand prize winner will be announced ahead of the final film speaker session on Sunday, January .All other shortlisted photographers will receive a pair of tickets to a festival session of their choice.The  Peebles Outdoor Film Festival will be held over the weekend of January -to-.Entry to the festival photography competition costs pound, with photographers able to submit up to five images.Deadline for entries is Friday, January .For entry forms and full details contact e. press@eastgatearts

title: room-inn-sandys-tontine-triumph
story: A PEEBLES historian has gone upmarket in her quest to discover the Royal Burghs past.Sandy Whitnell has previously researched and documented the depravity suffered in the town at the Peebles Poorhouse.From the late s the Combination Poorhouse on Rosetta Road was home to many down-on-their-luck locals.In a bid to find some balance, Sandy went from rags to riches with her next project - and has now charted the history of the glamorous Tontine Hotel.From her initial , word essay for a local history meeting, she decided to investigate the High Street hostelry even further.And this month The Public Rooms of the County has been published.The -page booklet provides readers with a remarkable journey from the hotels grand opening in  all the way through to its popular place on todays High Street.Sandy told us: "It was after Id done my talk on the Peebles poorhouse that I wanted to go to the other extreme and see where the wealthy were staying at the time."It seemed such a shame that the history of The Tontine Hotel hadnt been done before, so I initially wrote up , words."That was just the start."There were three prominent figures involved in the creation of the Tontine Hotel - local MP Sir John Montgomery, banker John Hay, and army captain Robert Nutler Campbell.Their aspirations for a prominent high-class hotel in Peebles led to  people purchasing shares to fund the project.Tontine, named after Italian economist Tonti, derives from the type of investment plan used.The Tontine was built at a cost of pound, - around pound, in todays money - and the doors were opened in .From its early days The Tontine was a popular meeting place for many organisations and societies in and around Peebles.It was also a busy destination for travellers arriving by coach and horse, with its stables being well used, in the days before the railway reached the town.And it wasnt just horses who were stabled at the Tontine, with reports from  of an elephant from Battys Travelling Menagerie dying while being kept at the Tontine.The Public Rooms of the County highlights the grandeur offered with the magnicent ballroom regarded as its crowning glory.Sandays enjoyable book also introduces readers to the vast array of characters who managed the hotel - from Frenchman Benoit Lenoir at the height of the Napoleonic wars and entrepreneurial James Cameron to the bullish Thomas Noble and heroic Duncan McPherson - until its sale into private ownership in the s.The purchase by William Borthwick and Duncan McPherson ended the Tontine arrangement, but the premises kept the name.Although the hotel was sold to a national chain in , it ed to private ownership more recently with the current proprietors Kate and Gordon Innes.Author Sandy admits she struck gold during her research with an enquiry at the National Records office in Edinburgh.She added: "The officer at the National Records produced three unopened boxes full of original documents relating to the hotel."It was an absolute treasure trove for any historian and has helped me produce a very detailed history of this much-loved hotel."The Public Rooms of the County, priced at pound, is available from The Tontine Hotel as well as Amazon.All profits from the sale of The Public Rooms of the County will be shared between the Peebles Foodbank and the Peebles Community Talking Books project.

title: happiness-borders-comes-dalai-lamas-blessing
story: THE Dalai Lama has given his blessing to a new course being run in the Borders which promises to make people happier and the world a better place.The eight-week course is designed by the Action for Happiness organisation - a UK based movement with over , members which takes action for a happier world.Entitled Exploring What Matters, the weekly courses will be offered in Peebles and Innerleithen in the New Year.It is a secular project based on science rather than faith and is open to people of all backgrounds.The course is backed by the Dalai Lama, who said: ldquoAs patron of Action for Happiness I am delighted to see the work being done by members of this movement to create a happier and more caring society."I wholeheartedly support the Exploring What Matters course and hope that many thousands of people will benefit from it and be inspired to take their own action to help create a happier world.Analysis of the course has found that it leaves people both happier and more pro-social, with participants reporting increases in levels of le satisfaction, mental wellbeing, compassion and social trust.Many say the course is le-changing.In Exploring What Matters, local groups meet for eight weeks, with each session exploring a big question.They start with "What really matters in le " and then "What really makes us happy ".These are followed by sessions on dealing with adversity, having good relationships, caring for others, and creating happier workplaces and communities.They end with "How can we create a happier world The first eight week course is being run in Peebles on a voluntary basis by Suzi Gibson and Laura Swan in Space, Greenside every Thursday starting on January .Suzi said: ldquoIrsquom very excited to be running this course because happier iniduals make for a happier community and I am passionate about bringing people together to discuss what matters. I canrsquot think of a better use of my time than helping myself and others be happier.The Innerleithen-based course is being run by Lois Hindley and Cath Shepheard and takes place at Innerleithen Church of Scotland every Wednesday starting on January .And whatrsquos even better is the cost of happiness is free, but the organisers do ask for a small donation to cover costs.If you would like to search for happiness contact Laura Swan at hello@lauraswan
